channel.title: Power Cord Overheating
channel.description:
On my laptop, it appears that I'm having a problem, and from my knowledge, it's not a cheap problem either. What is happening is my laptop power cord is extremely hot, and the fan isn't running. Basically it's melting my power cord, which means I probably have to go out and buy: - a new fan - a new socket for the power cord ('sif i remember what it's called)
I'm not to happy about this. Anyone know what else might be wrong, and how to fix it?

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @Hiaburi Hiaburi
item.description:
@Hiaburi wrote:

Lol, that’s what I did when my power cord went bad, Guess there was too much stress on it and the wires inside got crossed.

Read full topic

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

I’ve ordered a new power cord off of ebay and it’ll hopefully fix the problem. Thanks to everyone who posted advice.

Read full topic

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“magma828, post:1, topic:221391”][quote author=jonnywashere link=topic=290356.msg2342920#msg2342920 date=1216442454]
also make sure that u set the laptop down on a hard surface or it gets overheated and crashes something insinde it i ruined a nice $2,000 laptop from that
[/quote]
what the fuck?[/quote]

Don’t put it on a bed or a sofa and block the intake vents, basically.

Read full topic

item.title: Power Cord Overheating

@jonnywashere wrote:

also make sure that u set the laptop down on a hard surface or it gets overheated and crashes something insinde it i ruined a nice $2,000 laptop from that

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

Try turning the fans up via the BIOS.

As for the power cord…I suppose you would need a new cord if it has started to melt.

It could possibly be the fact the power cable may have a DC/AC alternator that may have taken a shit fit? Not enough current to kill the mobo, but enough for some serious heat, or to blow a cap…maybe for your fan?

Read full topic

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

[quote=“magma828, post:1, topic:221164”]Seems strange that the cable would get hot before the current in the mobo gets high enough to turn itself off…

Maybe the cables in the fan have short-circuited?[/quote]

I was thinking more along the lines of the power cord short-circuiting.

Read full topic

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

What laptop are you using and how old is the?

Read full topic

item.title: Power Cord Overheating
item.dc:creator: @Tico135 Tico
item.description:
@Tico135 wrote:

On my laptop, it appears that I’m having a problem, and from my knowledge, it’s not a cheap problem either. What is happening is my laptop power cord is extremely hot, and the fan isn’t running. Basically it’s melting my power cord, which means I probably have to go out and buy:

  • a new fan
  • a new socket for the power cord ('sif i remember what it’s called)

I’m not to happy about this. Anyone know what else might be wrong, and how to fix it?

Read full topic
